<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>

9702/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 128, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 102, 688, 532]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 565, 170, 581]]<|/det|>
## Formulae

Doppler effect for sound waves

resistors in parallel

\[m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{-31}\mathrm{kg}\]

\[N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\]

\[R = 8.31\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 346, 648, 367]]<|/det|>
\[k = 1.38\times 10^{-23}\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 378, 688, 399]]<|/det|>
\[G = 6.67\times 10^{-11}\mathrm{Nm}^2\mathrm{kg}^{-2}\]

\[\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{-12}\mathrm{Fm}^{-1}\] \[(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{-1})\]

\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]

\[\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\]

\[F = \rho gV\]

\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{V\pm V_{s}}\]

\[I = A n v q\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 819, 615, 853]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 101, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 571, 91]]<|/det|>
Underline **all** the SI base units in the following list.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 102, 799, 121]]<|/det|>
ampere coulomb current kelvin newton

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
A toy car moves in a horizontal straight line. The displacement s of the car is given by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 171, 529, 201]]<|/det|>
\[s = \frac{\nu^2}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 211, 665, 229]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) is the acceleration of the car and \(\nu\) is its final velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 242, 920, 276]]<|/det|>
State **two** conditions that apply to the motion of the car in order for the above equation to be valid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 917, 307]]<|/det|>
1 ...................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 320, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
2 ...................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 336, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 144, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
An experiment is performed to determine the acceleration of the car in **(b)**. The following measurements are obtained:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 411, 346, 429]]<|/det|>
\[s = 3.89 \text{ m} \pm 0.5\%\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 427, 376, 445]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = 2.75 \text{ m s}^{-1} \pm 0.8\%\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 181, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 459, 512, 477]]<|/det|>
Calculate the acceleration \(a\) of the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 583, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<form>a = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-2}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 583, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 613, 181, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 613, 759, 631]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty, to two significant figures, in \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 768, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 768, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 73, 180, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Use your answers in (c)(i) and (c)(ii) to determine the absolute uncertainty in the calculated value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 210, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
<form>absolute uncertainty = ............................................. $\text{ms}^{-2}$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 620, 89]]<|/det|>
A motor uses a wire to raise a block, as illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 98, 688, 300]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 317, 591, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 348, 920, 397]]<|/det|>
The base of the block takes a time of \(0.49 \mathrm{s}\) to move vertically upwards from level X to level Y at a constant speed of \(0.64 \mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) . During this time the wire has a strain of 0.0012. The wire is made of metal of Young modulus \(2.2 \times 10^{11} \text{Pa}\) and has a uniform cross-section.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 409, 826, 428]]<|/det|>
The block has a weight of \(1.4 \times 10^{4} \text{N}\). Assume that the weight of the wire is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 441, 146, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 441, 243, 459]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 472, 181, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 472, 504, 490]]<|/det|>
the cross-sectional area \(A\) of the wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 625, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
<form>A = .................................................... $\text{m}^2$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 626, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 657, 180, 675]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 656, 920, 691]]<|/det|>
the increase in the gravitational potential energy of the block for the movement of its base from X to Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 845, 920, 864]]<|/det|>
increase in gravitational potential energy = .................................................... J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 845, 920, 864]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 455, 88]]<|/det|>
The motor has an efficiency of \(56\%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 834, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate the input power to the motor as the base of the block moves from X to Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[468, 257, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<form>input power = .................................................... W [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 288, 144, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
The base of the block now has a uniform deceleration of magnitude \(1.3 \text{m} \text{s}^{-2}\) from level Y until the base of the block stops at level Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 801, 352]]<|/det|>
Calculate the tension \(T\) in the wire as the base of the block moves from Y to Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................... N [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 521, 146, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 521, 798, 539]]<|/det|>
The base of the block is at levels X, Y and Z at times \(t_{\mathrm{X}}\), \(t_{\mathrm{Y}}\) and \(t_{\mathrm{Z}}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 552, 920, 584]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with time \(t\) of the distance \(d\) of the base of the block from level X. Numerical values of \(d\) and \(t\) are not required.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 594, 670, 817]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 839, 534, 857]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 858, 920, 876]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 13]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 792, 91]]<|/det|>
A uniform beam AB is attached by a hinge to a wall at end A, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 920, 335]]<|/det|>
The beam has length \(0.50 \text{m}\) and weight \(W.\) A block of weight \(12 \text{N}\) rests on the beam at a distance of \(0.15 \text{m}\) from end B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 348, 920, 381]]<|/det|>
The beam is held horizontal and in equilibrium by a string attached between end B and a fixed point C. The string has a tension of \(17 \text{N}\) and is at an angle of \(50^{\circ}\) to the horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 394, 146, 412]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 917, 467]]<|/det|>
<form>................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 509, 917, 528]]<|/det|>
<form>................................................................................................................

<mark>[2]

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 562, 715, 581]]<|/det|>
Show that the vertical component of the tension in the string is \(13 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 640, 920, 658]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 672, 146, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 672, 725, 691]]<|/det|>
By taking moments about end A, calculate the weight \(W\) of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 871, 920, 890]]<|/det|>
<form>W = ....................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[522, 163, 920, 181]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... N [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 144, 214]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
The block is now moved closer to end A of the beam. Assume that the beam remains horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 242, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
State whether this change will increase, decrease or have no effect on the horizontal component of the force exerted on the beam by the hinge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 291, 920, 308]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 320, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Two blocks slide directly towards each other along a frictionless horizontal surface, as shown in Fig. 4.1. The blocks collide and then move as shown in Fig. 4.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 115, 816, 240]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[288, 250, 358, 268]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 250, 710, 268]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 280, 920, 343]]<|/det|>
Block X initially moves to the right with a momentum of \(0.37 \text{kg} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\). Block Y initially moves to the left with a momentum of \(0.65 \text{kg} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\). After the blocks collide, block X moves to the left back along its original path with a momentum of \(0.13 \text{kg} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\). Block Y also moves to the left after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 355, 144, 374]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 355, 529, 374]]<|/det|>
Block X has an initial kinetic energy of 0.30 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 384, 410, 403]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 603, 920, 622]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 635, 752, 653]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude of the momentum of block Y after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 772, 920, 791]]<|/det|>
<form>momentum = ............................................ $kg \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 772, 920, 791]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 744, 89]]<|/det|>
Block X exerts an average force of 7.7 N on block Y during the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 685, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate the time that the blocks are in contact with each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 275, 920, 293]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 306, 920, 323]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A microphone and cathode-ray oscilloscope (CRO) are used to analyse a sound wave of frequency \(5000\mathrm{Hz}\). The trace that is displayed on the screen of the CRO is shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 114, 680, 348]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 364, 532, 382]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 181, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 395, 650, 414]]<|/det|>
Determine the time-base setting, in \(\text{cm}^{- 1}\), of the CRO.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<form>time-base setting = ............................................. $\text{scm}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 583, 181, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 583, 920, 647]]<|/det|>
The intensity of the sound detected by the microphone is now increased from its initial value of \(I\) to a new value of \(3I\). The frequency of the sound is unchanged. Assume that the amplitude of the trace on the CRO screen is proportional to the amplitude of the sound wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 660, 744, 678]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.1, sketch the new trace shown on the screen of the CRO.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 660, 920, 678]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 691, 146, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 691, 803, 710]]<|/det|>
An arrangement for demonstrating interference using light is shown in Fig. 5.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 718, 798, 907]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 923, 591, 940]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 945, 551, 961]]<|/det|>
9702/22/F/M/23

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
The wavelength of the light from the laser is \(630\mathrm{nm}\). The light is incident normally on the double slit. The separation of the two slits is \(3.6 \times 10^{- 4}\mathrm{m}\). The perpendicular distance between the double slit and the screen is \(D\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
Coherent light waves from the slits form an interference pattern of bright and dark fringes on the screen. The distance between the centres of two adjacent bright fringes is \(4.0 \times 10^{- 3}\mathrm{m}\). The central bright fringe is formed at point P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 181, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 195, 787, 213]]<|/det|>
Explain why a bright fringe is produced by the waves meeting at point P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 288, 178, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 373, 306]]<|/det|>
Calculate distance \(D\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 443, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
<form>D = .................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 473, 144, 491]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
The wavelength \(\lambda\) of the light in **(b)** is now varied. This causes a variation in the distance \(x\) between the centres of two adjacent bright fringes on the screen. The distance \(D\) and the separation of the two slits are unchanged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 918, 568]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.3, sketch a graph to show the variation of \(x\) with \(\lambda\) from \(\lambda = 400 \text{nm}\) to \(\lambda = 700 \text{nm}\). Numerical values of \(x\) are not required.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 575, 668, 756]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 12 V and negligible internal resistance is connected to a uniform resistance wire XY, a fixed resistor and a variable resistor, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 388, 920, 422]]<|/det|>
The fixed resistor has a resistance of \(5.0\Omega\). The current in the battery is \(2.7\mathsf{A}\) and the current in the fixed resistor is \(1.5\mathsf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 435, 181, 454]]<|/det|>
